text: we're interested in an area of research
called metabolomics metabolomics is the
newest of the so called ohmic sciences
most people have probably heard of
genomics and proteomics where
researchers are profiling genes and
proteins what happens in metabolomics is
we're profiling metabolites metabolites
are low mass molecules they're the small
molecules in the cell and our motivation
behind looking at metabolites compared
to genes and proteins as that
metabolites actually the substrates
involved though the entity the chemical
entities that are involved in the
reactions they're literally what's being
transformed inside of the cell during
metabolism we have a lot of different
instruments that we use for looking at
metabolites but one of our particular
interests is trying to anatomically
localize metabolites within a specific
piece of tissue one of the ways in which
metabolites are localized within tissue
is by using a technique an analytical
approach called mass spectrometry what
happens in mass spectrometry is that
molecules are ions are isolated and then
the masses of those ions are measured
and by knowing the mass of these
compounds we can then figure out what
these compounds are if they're sugars
amino acids or proteins the technique
that's typically used for imaging
molecules inside on a tissue is called
MALDI or matrix assisted laser
desorption ionization the way that MALDI
works is by using a multi-plate and the
samples are deposited the tissue samples
a section of a tissue sample is
deposited on a MALDI plate and then this
is measured using a mass spectrometer
in order to get the molecules to ionize
a liquid substances applied to the
sample known as a matrix MALDI the M and
MALDI stands for matrix
unfortunately that matrix although it
helps us it helps out with us with our
ability to ionize these molecules it
also shows up in the mass spectrometer
and it shows up in the low mass region
of the mass spectra and this is the
exact region where the metabolites are
so MALDI works very well for looking at
proteins which are much heavier than the
region where the matrix is but it causes
significant interference problems when
we're looking at metabolites so we've
developed an approach which is matrix
list or does not use a matrix and this
is a technique called nano structure
initiator mass spectrometry or NIMS so I
just quickly want to walk you through
the general steps in performing a NIMS
experiment to do NIMS we start with a
custom synthesized NIMS chip that looks
like this we didn't use a device called
a cryo microtome which allows us to cut
very thin sections of tissues that we
then transfer on top of the nihms plate
we didn't take the nihms plate or the
nihms chip and we deposit it on to the
MALDI plate and secure it we take the
MALDI plate with the MEMS chip attached
and we put it in an instrument such as
this one which is an ABC X 5800 topped
off this is a mass spectrometer
we didn't use this instrument and
specifically the laser in this
instrument to go across step-by-step
across the tissue in each specific place
that the laser hits causes the tissue to
desorb or causes the molecules in that
tissue to fly up into the gas phase and
then which we detect them using the toff
or the time-of-flight component of the
mass spectrometer my name is Gary paddy
and I'm at the Scripps Research
Institute and what you're seeing here is
a BCI x50 5600 cough cough and this is
housed in the Center for mass
spectrometry at the Scripps Research
Institute
